Two-sided FDR-corrected Wilcoxon rank-sum test; n.s. not significant. All boxplots are the median with the interquartile range, and the error bars are the 1.5-times interquartile range (whiskers). c, Relative abundance plots of bacterial and fungal taxa of skin sites, aggregated by physiologic features defined in (a) of DOCK8-deficient patients with age-matched healthy volunteers. Figure 2 . Virome analysis of skin microbiome of DOCK8-deficient patients. a, Relative abundance of viral families from total microbial reads identified on DOCK8-deficient patients' (n=27) skin from different sites. Body site codes as given in Supplementary Figure  1(a) . b, Mean relative abundance heat map of Polyomaviridae species detected on DOCK8deficient patients' skin. c, Of the two major subtypes, MCV-1 and MCV-2 1,2 , the vast majority of the 77 MCV-positive sites on 14 DOCK8 deficient patients (96%) were predominated (99% mean relative abundance) by MCV-1. Phylogenetic tree of core SNPs from Snippy/Gubbins reconstructed MCV-1 genome alignments. Blue tick marks show the positions of SNPs across the 190 kb MCV-1 genome (U60315.1). Based on core SNPS, two siblings (D8_Pt05, D8_Pt06) carried the same strain. d, Mean relative abundances of human DNA viruses from the Herepsviridae (n=11) and Anelloviridae (n=7) detected in low abundances in DOCK8 patients' skin (TTV is Torque Teno Virus). D8_Pt12 harbors 10 different species from 4 distinct genera of Anelloviridae.

Supplementary Figure 3 . Human skin-associated eukaryotic viral discovery through reference-free de novo assembly. Flowchart of de novo metagenomics read assembly and contig classification done on each sample independently and then merged. Reads were filtered and assembled into 227,924 contigs (contiguous sequences) over 750nt in size, quality filtered for GC content and complexity, which were then classified based upon BLAST hit. Blastn assignment to best hit revealed that ~ 125,000 of the contigs were small (1-2 kb) bacterial contigs with low coverage and an additional ~ 90,000 contigs were also likely to be bacterial (best hit with lower threshold for query coverage). 10,435 contigs were eukaryotic viruses with high coverage; of which 8,631 contigs were assigned to the Papillomaviridae family. Putative Papillomaviridae sequences were filtered to select full-length genomes, compared with the Papillomavirus Episteme (PaVe) database to classify known genomes (>90% similarity) and clustered at 95% identity using SPICi and Mash 3,4 resulting in 250 non-redundant HPV genomes. New types and species were classified based upon L1 sequence. HPV genomes from the same genera share at least 60% L1 similarity, the same species share at least 71% L1 similarity, and the same types share at least 90% L1 similarity 5, 6 . New species were further confirmed by PCR of the putative L1 sequence from the original skin DNA. 1 BLAST requirement hit cover >25% of the contig. 2 No hit coverage requirement. 3 208 clusters and 42 singletons. Figure 4 . Mapping microbial dark matter with de novo assembled genomes. a, Boxplots showing percent of shotgun metagenomics reads aligned to reference database before and after addition of 250 HPV genomes. Graphed as median of all samples per individual (n=188 independent biological samples; FDR-corrected Kruskal-Wallis test comparing read mapping in all samples to reference database and after addition of assembled HPV genomes; p =5.5e-5). All boxplots are the median with the interquartile range, and the error bars are the 1.5times interquartile range (whiskers) and outliers (points). b, Flowchart of non-Papillomaviridae viral contigs assignment as potential novel viruses. c, Phylogenetic tree of members of the Anelloviridae family depicting putative novel Torque teno viruses assembled from viral and unmapped reads. A novel anellovirus genotype has been defined as the ORF1 gene having <90% shared nucleotide identity when aligned to any reference genotype, whereas designation as a novel anellovirus species requires <50% sequence identity 7 . Taxa are colored by genera, with contigs depicted in a darker shade of the corresponding genus color.

Human papillomavirus phylogenetic tree constructed by alignment of the L1 gene sequence of each genome using Muscle. Tree construction was performed using FastTree and visualized by FigTree, depicting all reference HPVs and 250 HPV types assembled from viral and unmapped reads. Color codes highlight the five HPV genera (Alpha -lavender, Beta -magenta, Gammagreen, Mu -cyan, Nu -pink). Reference types are depicted in black, novel types are depicted in colors corresponding to genus. Figure 6 . Diversity of HPV on DOCK8-deficient patients' skin. a, Relative abundances of HPV species on DOCK8-deficient patients' (n=27) skin. Body site codes as given in Supplementary Figure 1(a) . b, Boxplots comparing percent viral reads mapped to HPV genera before and after addition of assembled HPV genomes to reference database (n=188 independent biological samples). All boxplots are the median with the interquartile range, and the error bars are the 1.5-times interquartile range (whiskers) and outliers (points). Two-sided Wilcoxon-rank sum test; p=7.6e -09 , 2.4e -04 and 5.67e -09 for alpha-beta, beta-gamma and beta-mu HPV genera comparison, respectively, before addition of assembled HPV genomes to reference database. Two-sided Wilcoxon-rank sum test; p=0.053 for beta-gamma HPV genera comparison after addition of assembled HPV genomes to reference database. c, Number of HPV types detected on each DOCK8-deficient patient (n=27, in numerical order), arranged by skin site sampled. Note that sites Hp, Ic, Mb, Ph were not sampled in first seven patients. Figure 7 . RNA virome analysis of DOCK8-deficient patients' skin. a, Mean relative abundance comparison of RNA and DNA reads aligned to HPV genera (left panel) and Polyomavirus species (right panel). b, Phylogenetic trees of RhinovirusA and RhinovirusB species depicting the novel Rhinoviruses assembled from RNA reads. The Picronaviridae study group defines novelty of a Rhinovirus genotype by the coding sequence of the conserved VP1 gene; an HRV type should have at least 13 % (HRV-A) or 12 % (HRV-B) nucleotide divergence from all other HRV types 8,9 . With primers designed at terminal contig sequences and cDNA derived from the original patient RNA, we amplified across the gaps, Sanger sequenced and constructed two full genomes of putative novel Rhinoviruses variant and genotype (RhinovirusA genome detected in a single patient and a RhinovirusB genome detected in two other patients), with 89% and 80% nucleotide identity to the conserved VP1 gene of the closest genotype (A60 and B93), respectively. VP1 gene sequences were aligned using Muscle, tree construction was performed using FastTree and visualized by FigTree. Novel genomes depicted in Blue.
